title: When will clinical human trials for a Zika vaccine begin?
preds:
According to the general news and GJP consensus. 
Anthony Fauci announced that clinical trials for a Zika vaccine are expected to start this summer sponsored by the NIH, and this September sponsored by a pharmaceutical company.
Congress has still not approved the expected $1.9 billion Zika Virus research funding, but this should not delay the clinical trials of the vaccine.

https://www.statnews.com/2016/06/20/zika-vaccine-inovio/
These people seem to think they have the okey-dokey stamp to proceed quite soon.

Journalists refuse to go to Brazil because of Zika epidemic.
BBC staff refuse to travel to cover Rio Olympics because they are frightened of catchin... - Daily Mail
https://apple.news/AbOFs4elMTq-iliD4epH7gQ
Still nothing showing on clinicaltrials.gov. But I'm still very confident this will happen this year.

------- GLS-5700 wants to END by November, but isn't recruiting yet
----------------------- Protein Science Corp wanted to start in May, yet claims to start in July, while they may not have federal funding
---------------- Saint Louis Uni wants to start in "several month" to come, but seem to have NIH funding

I am forecasting based on the general news reports and GJP consensus. 
Funding for Zika Virus research is still stuck in Congress, but this should not delay the start of clinical trials.
Consensus has moved ahead of me. Keeping pace.

Clinical trials confirms Zika vaccine trial, even though no participants have been recruited yet. Will increase to 100% once they have people enrolled.
https://clinicaltrials.gov/show/NCT02809443

The vaccine trial has been approved and is currently taking volunteers: https://clinicaltrials.gov/show/NCT02809443 I think the probability of a problem preventing the trial from beginning at this point is much less than 1%. @Raahul_Kumar I hope that's sufficient evidence for you now :-P
People will risk taking it & ethics will permit testing bec danger do great. And civilian pressure
Nice - nearly full catch up of consensus!
Several recent news stories say first round of human testing will begin "in the next few months" or words to that effect.

Two New Vaccines Show Complete Protection in Lab Tests  http://www.cnbc.com/2016/06/28/two-new-zika-vaccines-show-complete-protection-in-lab-tests.html?utm_content=buffer10bc9&utm_medium=social&utm_source=twitter.com&utm_campaign=buffer

Phase I (safety) human trials about to begin (1) "The phase I trial will assess the safety and effectiveness of the Zika DNA vaccine GLS-5700 in 40 healthy volunteers...  The first volunteers will receive the vaccine in the next few weeks and interim results from the trial are expected to be released later this year."
1:  http://www.webmd.com/news/20160621/zika-vaccine-trial A company has been awarded the contract to manufacture the Zika vaccine for ultimate FDA approval and large scale manufacture (2): "Emergent BioSolutions wins contract to develop Zika vaccine ...Emergent will provide drug development and manufacturing for an early-stage Zika vaccine — one of several in the pre-clinical stages — in preparation for a Food and Drug Administration review process that could open it up to broader consumption. The vaccine could be given a designation called the emergency use authorization that could hasten the approval process. It could reach stage-one clinical trials by early 2017."
2:  https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/capitalbusiness/emergent-biosolutions-wins-contract-to-develop-zika-vaccine/2016/06/27/8f425472-3c93-11e6-84e8-1580c7db5275_story.html Meanwhile a second article on the same "Emergent" story says   "Emergent expects to have the vaccine candidate ready for clinical trials by the end of the year."
3: http://www.baltimoresun.com/business/bs-bz-emergent-manufactures-zika-vaccine-20160627-story.html
Based on news of Zika vaccine trials by two different companies.
Looks like Inovio has confirmed starting these in next few weeks! Raising to 100%

Saint Louis University will be conducting a human clinical trial in the near future and seems to have support from NIH. http://www.news-medical.net/news/20160624/SLU-to-conduct-human-clinical-trial-of-vaccine-to-protect-people-from-Zika-virus.aspx

http://arstechnica.com/science/2016/06/first-experimental-zika-vaccine-gets-nod-from-fda-moves-to-human-trials/ The US Food and Drug Administration on Monday approved the first human trial of an experimental Zika vaccine, according to a joint announcement by the two companies behind the new therapy. The companies, Inovio Pharmaceuticals, Inc., based in Pennsylvania, and GeneOne Life Science, Inc., based in South Korea, said that their DNA-based vaccine candidate, dubbed GLS-5700, will be given to 40 people in a phase I trial. The trial will start “in the next weeks,” the companies said, and could yield results later this year.

Small phase 1 clinical trial has been announced and is expected to begin within "a few weeks". While delays are possible or even probable I don't believe they will be so significant as to push the start of the trial past 1st jan.

http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/the-u-s-takes-its-first-shot-at-zika/?WT.mc_id=SA_DD_20160622 "The first candidate Zika vaccine is headed for the earliest stages of human trials in the next few weeks. By August a similar vaccine backed by the National Institutes of Health is expected to begin testing among human volunteers. And by winter several more vaccine candidates that employ various forms of the virus are slated for human testing, supported by funds from the NIH."
Most news outlets confirming that Inovio will start clinical trials in a matter of weeks, given the timelines involved I think it is acceptable to go to 100%, something I normally avoid.
Inovio's vaccine has been FDA-approved and will be tested "in the next weeks." [http://arstechnica.com/science/2016/06/first-experimental-zika-vaccine-gets-nod-from-fda-moves-to-human-trials/]

FDA approves first clinical trial (phase I - safety) "The first people could be injected within a few weeks, said Inovio President and CEO Dr. Joseph Kim. Inovio, of Plymouth Meeting, Pa., and GeneOne Life Science, of Seoul, South Korea, will make the vaccine."
https://www.statnews.com/2016/06/20/zika-vaccine-inovio/

The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) gave a green light Monday to the first human trial of a potential Zika vaccine. Inovio Pharmaceuticals and GeneOne Life Science are at the helm of the study.

A Zika Vaccine Is Now Ready for Human Test Subjects  The CDC has granted clinical trial approval for this experimental Zika vaccine named GLS-5700 which is the result of a collaboration between Inovio Pharmaceuticals of Pennsylvania and GeneOne Life Science of South Korea.  Earlier today, the companies announced a phase I study "with 40 healthy subjects to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and efficacy of the drug."  Clinical trials are expected to start in a few weeks and results are expected later this year.

Approved for trials. To begin in weeks.
http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/zika-virus-outbreak/company-gets-ok-test-new-zika-virus-vaccine-n595571

https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/to-your-health/wp/2016/06/20/scientists-announce-important-zika-milestone-first-vaccine-ready-for-human-trials/
Haven't started yet, but will soon.
I am forecasting based on the general news reports and GJP consensus.

Genetic manipulations have reach a revolutionary stage of applied technology. Zika is in the wings with a potent summer seasonal impact possible.  I'd say a 6 months to a year from the first domestically derived case(s), which could be in August.
Funding to fight Zika Virus was approved by Congress earlier this week.

Looks like preparations are underway.... and this is not from  pharmo company literature....
http://www.defense.gov/News-Article-View/Article/795226/walter-reed-scientists-test-zika-vaccine-candidate

Any disease will get prompt attention if it threatens well-off white folks with babies that can't get into Harvard even with substantial donations.  Several firms have said they are pretty close to human trials now.  It is never wise to bet against a virus, but this Q does not require the trials to be successful, only to occur.  A good followup question might be about how this turns out.

The National Institutes of Health is “very aggressively pursuing” a potential vaccine to combat the Zika virus and hopes to have an early safety study of a vaccine by September 2016, said National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases director Anthony Fauci, MD.

As of June 3, 2016, Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the NIAID, still "hopes to have an early safety study of a vaccine by September of 2016." [http://news.yahoo.com/news/video/yahoo-news-now-zika-virus-165154657.html]

http://www.c-span.org/video/?410139-1/cdc-director-tom-frieden-addresses-zika-virus-response
2016-05-26 CDC Director Thomas "Tom" Frieden M.D. on Zika Virus Response Efforts at the National Press Club
"NIH is doing terrific work...They've got five different potential vaccine candidates. They expect to be in phase one trials in September, phase two trials beginning early next year."
Concerns are rising but no new news. Reiterating
Congress still has not approved funding to fight the Zika Virus which may slow down starting vaccine clinical trials and vaccine production.

This study about the discovery of Zika in the 1940's, and the other viruses not yet studied, may yet lead to vaccines and cures if enough resources are dedicated to the crisis.
Zika Discoverer Tells Of 'Human Bait,' Draws Monkeys In Overlooked Archive
NPR - 4h ago
Back in 1947, Alexander John Haddow made a discovery that didn't seem particularly important. He was part of a team doing research on yellow fever in Uganda, and he identified a new virus that was making a monkey in his lab sick.

I don't know anything about the stages involved in preparing vaccines, but I can see that this is another question where one can use the strategy of optimizing for an early resolution.

In his testimony to Congress on 12 May, Dr. Anthony S Fauci, Director, reiterated his earlier statements that human clinical trials are expected to start in the fall of 2016. https://www.niaid.nih.gov/about/directors/congress/Documents/NIAID-Zika-Testimony-5-12-2016.pdf

inactivated virus vaccine. Preclinical testing of the vaccine candidate is underway, and human clinical studies, supported by NIAID and WRAIR, are expected to start in the fall of 2016. "

http://www.philly.com/philly/business/20160524_Local_biotechs_race_to_develop_Zika_vaccine.html
Sanofi is apparently considered "local" in Philadelphia because its US hq is in the Poconos, in Pennsylvania but not especially near Philadelphia.  A few grafs in, they say they are hoping to start human testing this year.  There are a dozen or so other firms working on this, so it seems likely somebody will start human trials in the next several months. Active participants do not include the Very Big Pharma firms, because those folks expect natural immunity to kick in "within the next 5 to 10 years," limiting their ability to command extortionate profits, no matter who is, shall we say, inconvenienced in the meantime.  Anything wrong with this picture?  (Full disclosure: This graf is gratuitous calumny not related to the GJ question.)

Anthony Fauci from the NIH stated on ABC TV this morning that most likely the clinical trials for the vaccine will begin sometime in 2017 rather than this year, but he may be more conservative in his estimation.

If I understand this article correctly... the cloning of Zika means they can make it safer to test on people...
"Researchers claim that by adapting the virus, they could make a safe vaccine enough to make the body ward off the infection without actually causing the disease.
Experts hope that that a candidate will be ready for testing in the coming months. However, it could be years before there can be a safe and effective vaccine that can be offered to the general public.
While several groups of scientists are working on Zika vaccines, this is the first time the actual Zika strain was replicated." http://www.natureworldnews.com/articles/22420/20160518/zika-virus-clone-speed-up-vaccine-scientists.htm And just found this...
http://www.abc2news.com/news/health/johns-hopkins-scientist-to-test-zika-vaccine  "I have the vaccine and we're now... just today what the FDA will require of us to give us permission to start the human clinical trials," said August.
As opposed to those pursuing vaccines, which would contain a live virus, August is relying upon one of his own discoveries---a means of delivering cells injected with the DNA code of the virus to a person's own immune system to fight off infection.' "Others talk about 10 years to invent and develop a new vaccine,” said August, “We're going to do this in about a year." 
That's just the first phase of the trials, which may be tested on as few as 20 to 30 subjects."

As I've mentioned multiple times before, there are no Zika vaccine trials mentioned. Not 1. January and June are completely irrational, and to be frank I doubt 2018, even 2019 would be very lucky.  https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/results?term=zika&Search=Search

http://www.cnn.com/2016/05/17/health/zika-virus-clone-scientist/ "The U.S. National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases has created a trial vaccine for similar viruses that can be used as a starting point for a Zika vaccine, and the Jenner Institute has conducted trials with mice and aims to hold clinic trials by 2017."

"Testing a potential vaccine [in humans] for the Zika virus will start in September, Anthony Fauci, the director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Disease, confirmed." [https://morningconsult.com/alert/testing-zika-vaccine-start-september/] Inovio is also planning human trials in 2016 after successful trials in monkeys. [http://ir.inovio.com/news/news-releases/news-releases-details/2016/Inovio-Pharmaceuticals-Zika-VaccineProduces-Robust-Immune-Responses-in-Non-Human-Primates/default.aspx] At this point, the only thing holding them both back would be if the FDA puts a halt on the process for some as-yet unknown reason.
NIAID is still saying it will start human trials of a vaccine on 80 people in September. This is now sounding like a confident prediction rather than a hope.
No additional news on this topic in the last week.
The problem is urgent. The search for an effective vaccine will be a race with many entrants.

Still seems on track for late this year... "Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID), said this month that NIAID plans to begin tests of a Zika vaccine in September 2016 with the hope of starting a large efficacy study in 2017 in a country with a high rate of infection. That vaccine study “should take anywhere from one year to three years to prove that it works or does not work,” Fauci said at a briefing at a Pan American Health Organization conference on Zika."

http://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/national/article76863037.html  Rep. Ami Bera of Elk Grove, Calif., is tracking the plans for the vaccine’s clinical trials. Bera, a physician, attended a May 5 briefing on the development of a vaccine at the National Institutes of Health. . . .  Bera commended U.S. National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases Chief Anthony Fauci for the speed with which the vaccine was developed. The institute plans to test the vaccine in 80 people in September, according to Science Magazine. If the vaccine proves to be safe, additional studies will be conducted. “When Dr. Fauci initially indicated that he was hopeful that we’d have a vaccine by the end of the year, that, in my mind – to come up with a brand new vaccine that quickly, you know – seemed a stretch,” Bera said. “So the science behind how they got to a place where we’ll be able to go into phase one clinical trials is fascinating.”

USPI in pre-IND discussions with FDA.   http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/us-phytotherapy-successfully-tests-a-viable-treatment-for-zika-virus-300266147.html  (Note: the successful testing referred to in title is in cell culture.)
https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/results?term=zika There are now 4 clinical trials going but none of them involve a zika vaccine.

May 3rd, NIAID plans to begin tests of a vaccine made in its labs in September in 80 people, said Fauci, who spoke at a press conference held at a meeting on Zika virus risk communication challenges in Washington, D.C. If the vaccine proves safe and capable of stimulating relevant immune responses, he said NIAID plans in the first quarter of 2017 to launch what he called a phase 2b study “in a country that has a very high rate of infection.” That study would enroll thousands of volunteers.  “If in the early part of 2017 we still have major outbreaks in South America and in the Caribbean, we may show that it’s effective or not within a year,” Fauci said.

http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-35727047 http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/zika-virus-indias-bharat-biotech-will-take-10-years-introduce-vaccine-1542161 There are 2 companies looking to develop Zuma vaccines. Both are looking to push on, the first to start trials gets good news coverage, hopefully more funding. NIH sound positive, Bharat more cautious.
More I read about it, more it seems that the trials will begin around September. However, as with most things in life, delays are likely. So taking 9 in 10 odds progressively for each bucket
Confirming previous forecast.  NIH vaccine now ?2018 (Fauci) but other companies likely will have preliminary trials earlier.

Pharos Biologicals intends to start human trials this fall: http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/pharos-biologicals-conducting-tests-of-a-novel-zika-vaccine-300260552.html#continue-jump Note sure how accurate such predictions are, as the FDA is able to stop progression to clinical trials at its discretion.
upgrading since another company says it will begin testing this year: http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/pharos-biologicals-conducting-tests-of-a-novel-zika-vaccine-300260552.html#continue-jump

As per links below @Anneinak and @Intriligator, at least two vaccine candidates - from Pharos and Inovio - are still scheduled for Phase 1 trials before the end of this year. Adjusting slightly upwards from 85%.
http://www.theglobaldispatch.com/pharos-to-begin-phase-1-clinical-trials-of-its-zika-vaccine-candidate-this-fall-35305/ Pharos To Begin Phase 1 Clinical Trials Of Its Zika Vaccine Candidate This Fall
Even the 10% is hugely optimistic given how long it usually takes to develop an effective vaccine: http://www.historyofvaccines.org/content/articles/vaccine-development-testing-and-regulation

Too early for vaccine trials but will be keeping an eye on this link.     The relationship between dengue and zika is likely helpful for those working to develop the vaccine     http://www.zikavirusnet.com/clinical-trials.html

The 2nd half of 2016 will be ringing with Zika all over the news. It will be imperative to act on it.
Vaccine development has come a long way. It will be expedited.
More Zika headlines to hit after olympics.

http://www.dailymercury.com.au/news/zika-virus-vaccine-should-not-be-expected-soon/3010424/ ""The fact that Zika is closely related to yellow fever and Japanese encephalitis viruses (both of which have effective vaccines), offers hope that the fast-tracked preparation of a candidate vaccine is feasible."   "However, because the virus poses the most risk to pregnant women, clinical trials will pose huge challenges. "Performing clinical trials on pregnant women would provide ethical and practical challenges to overcome before licensure is granted for administration to the general public." "Despite the fact that a candidate vaccine could be at the pre-clinical trial stage by the end of 2016, it could take years for the clinical trials to be approved and conducted. "While attaining ethical approval for, and performing, tests of vaccine safety and efficacy in humans can be laboriously slow at the best of times, the due process for any prototype vaccine that is given to pregnant women is understandably subject to rigorous scrutiny. "This is especially pertinent to Zika since the gravest manifestation of infection affects pregnancy."
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  Must all clinical trials encompass all demographics?  Couldn't they do a Phase I clinical trial involving men only?  The question doesn't require that the clinical trial be for every population, nor does it require what level clinical trial it should be,  so I think that would qualify.
OK, going back to my initial instincts and taking the under. Planning Fallacy and all that.

I had initially barbelled the forecast as I thought it would either be rushed through or take more time. Sanofi researcher (http://hereandnow.wbur.org/2016/04/20/zika-vaccine-development) seems pretty confident that they will start in first half of 17 so will reduce barbell but taking it mainly from the pre-2017 forecast, as the concern around Zika is not yet close to matching that of Ebola (which was my baseline disease).

Decreasing slightly the likelihood of a vaccine before January 2017 based on article at link:    This study, using laboratory methods, indicates that prior or co- infection with Dengue virus is likely to enhance Zika virus infection through a process known as antibody-dependent  enhancement (ADE) .    A similar phenomenon is already known to occur between different strains of dengue virus, a close relative of Zika and results in greater severity of symptoms when it occurs.  This means the "wrong" vaccine could enhance severity of Zika infection.   Alternatively, as discussed in the article, the possibility also exists to combine Zika and Dengue vaccine in the same preparation to protect against both.
http://biorxiv.org/content/early/2016/04/25/050112

1. It takes a very long time to get vaccines ready for trial. 
2. Zika virus is not a major and immediate threat to European or American life.

2016-formulation 
2017- request fast track approval / begin trails.
No additional news on this topic in the last week.

The amount of approvals required for clinical trials in humans is, under normal circumstances, huge and time-consuming. Hard to see Zika trials occurring quickly, particularly as it's a "new" , or at least previously unrecognized, disease

Zika virus is a flavivirus like Dengue and Yellow fever. Looking into the history of these two well-known diseases I found that both were discovered and studied many years before a vaccine attempt was performed;
       Yellow fever: first studies around 1900, then the studies of Theiler on the virus (1930) and subsequent vaccine development (1937) that lead to the first human trial (1938).
      Dengue: Early efforts to understand the virus dated around 1956, vaccine trial on humans by US Naval Medical Research Center performed in 2006. No approved vaccine developed yet. Based only on the history of these two I would be doubtful of having something concrete in a short time, nevertheless according to NIH experts Zika is very well understood (meaning vaccine progress is positive) due to the extensive studies of previous flavivirus. 
Finally, I am basing most of my forecast on the tentative vaccine timeline found in this video below (jump to minute 41)
https://videocast.nih.gov/Summary.asp?bhjs=0&File=19561&bhcp=1 Any suggestions?

http://www.fool.com/investing/general/2016/04/16/the-race-to-cure-the-zika-virus-is-on-and-this-com.aspx " . . . if you want to count the number of possible Zika players, you'll need to use both hands. 1) "Inovio Pharmaceuticals  . .  and GeneOne Life Science announced a partnership back in January to test a DNA-based vaccine to treat the Zika virus. Considering that both companies have solid backgrounds in DNA-based vaccine development, they may be able to bring a candidate to human clinical trials by the second half of this year. 2) "NewLink Genetics. . . . Perhaps best known for its cancer immunotherapy development platform, NewLink has experience in developing vaccines for flaviviruses, and its partnership with Merck (which has the deep pockets) should allow a potential cure to be funneled into clinical trials, assuming it shows promise in preclinical studies.  3) "Drug giant Sanofi . . . In early March it announced that it had assembled a team of 80 in-house experts to accelerate the research and development of a vaccine. Sanofi developed the first regulatory-approved vaccine for dengue, a similar mosquito-borne illness, which it believes could help expedite research and development of a Zika virus cure. Similar to Inovio, Sanofi could be in clinical trials by the second half of this year if all goes well. 4)" . . . In January, GlaxoSmithKline announced that it was weighing the development of a Zika virus vaccine considering its prior research into dengue. As the two infectious diseases are similar, GSK may be able to lop years off the development process for a vaccine. 5) ". . . Cerus. . .  isn't directly involved in curing the Zika virus, but does have its novel and Food and Drug Administration-approved Intercept Blood System. Cerus' Intercept Blood System can be used to proactively combat transfusion-based transmission. Keep in mind that this works well beyond just Zika, but it's an important step to possibly ensuring the disease isn't spread through blood transfusions. HOWEVER, " . . .  the best solution might just belong to Intrexon,. . .  which has taken a unique approach to combatting the Zika virus. Last summer, Interxon acquired Oxitec, a company involved in biologic insect controls. . . .  Oxitec genetically modified male Aedes aegypti mosquitoes, allowing these mosquitoes to pass along a genetic mutation to the next generation of Aedes aegypti mosquitoes. This new genetic insertion kills the new generation of mosquitoes before they reach the reproductive adult stage. In simpler terms, Oxitec developed a method to dramatically reduce/control the aedes aegypti mosquito population. Efficacy tests in Brazil, Panama, and the Cayman Islands demonstrated a 92% to 99% reduction in the Aedes aegypti mosquito population, which may also translate into a substantial reduction or elimination of other serious mosquito-borne illnesses such as dengue. . . . in March the FDA announced that it found Intrexon's genetically engineered male mosquitoes to be environmentally safe, which is another big hurdle cleared. "The big question is whether affected countries will opt for Intrexon's perceived-to-be ready solution or not. Intrexon is counting on plentiful government contracts to drive its Zika virus program growth. Some Wall Street analysts view combating Zika as a $200 million to $400 million annual opportunity for Intrexon. However, coordinated containment efforts by the World Health Organization and other health agencies often stamp out infectious diseases before they have an opportunity to reach pandemic potential. 
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  After describing 5 different teams working on a zika vaccine, several of which may have a vaccine ready for clinical trial in a few months, this piece suggests that zika research money may go into biological control instead.  hm.
Sandofi is closest to starting a clinical human trials on a Zika Virus vaccine based on their Dengue Fever Virus vaccine as reported on CNBC today.
More cases on Western civilization must be seen before this moves to profit model and risk evaluation.
I think that they will start happening soon, but not too soon because the risks might be too large.

This week, Mrs Roussef and the parliament that is firing her as I type agreed on the approval of an unproven medicine. Still this week, CDC announced the US scare level should be reduced. So who needs trials after all?
Money is in the panic. The CDC will run this opportunity like crazy to get money.  The CDC spent $5B for Ebola. This should get almost as much because it spreads through mosquitos... Scary stuff.

http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/zika-vaccine-could-solve-one-problem-while-stoking-another/ THIS ARTICLE DESCRIBES SOME OF THE CHALLENGES IN DESIGNING CLINICAL TRIALS FOR ZIKA: ". . .  Zika-linked Guillain Barre Syndrome (GBS) [a disease which causes paralysis that is sometimes fatal but more often reversible] is stoking concerns that a vaccine designed to protect patients against Zika could inadvertently provoke more cases of the autoimmune condition. . . . “Understanding the cause of GBS is going to be very important for vaccine development.” The logic behind these concerns is relatively straightforward: If exposure to that virus can fuel GBS—by some estimates in as many as one in 5,000 cases—might the presence of a weakened or dead form of virus within the vaccine provoke GBS cases, too? Like a flu or polio vaccine, a shot designed to protect against Zika would need to contain some form of the virus in order to stimulate antibody protection against it. . . . “There will be a risk. . . .  says Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases. Yet, “the risk of not having a vaccine overwhelms the risk of GBS,” he says. . . . At issue is what level of risk is acceptable.  . . .  analysis of past French Polynesian Zika patients . . .  suggests that exposure to Zika exacerbates the baseline GBS threat some 20-fold. Fauci and others, however, say they are not yet convinced that The Lancet figure (one in 5,000 Zika patients) is the final word. An estimated four out of five patients with Zika virus are asymptomatic. So if scientists track such asymptomatic individuals for GBS, perhaps that statistic could change—likely dropping the chances of how often Zika-linked GBS occurs, they contend. More studies need to be conducted. "But scientists are also racing against the threat of an evolving pandemic. The first stage of clinical trials for at least one potential vaccine candidate is slated to begin in September, according to Fauci.  There are no plans to push that timeline back, he says. . . . .
. . . 
"At the heart of the consternation about vaccines is why GBS appears to be tied to Zika in the first place.  . . . From a vaccine-development perspective, it would be particularly troubling if  [the virus itself directly attacks neural cells and destabilizes the myelin sheath around them or damages axons] . . . .because it is hard to control immune response—especially when scientists are not sure what facet of the virus may set off that cascade of action. Unfortunately, preliminary data suggests that this feared immune response is exactly what is happening, . . . . "Scientists are also looking to past GBS studies to devise plans about how to sidestep this potential threat. One idea: if GBS is caused by an immune response from the body, perhaps using a killed virus vaccine could allay this issue. But even then there are no guarantees. “The question is, does part of the virus look like human proteins or peptides that generate the autoimmune reaction?” . . .  If that is the case, then perhaps the presence of those substances would still cause GBS . . . It’s too early to say,” agrees Monath, chief scientific and chief operating officer for the Infectious Disease division of NewLink Genetics, a biopharmaceutical firm. ". . .  analysis of GBS suggests the incidence of Zika increases by about 20 percent with every 10-year increase in age . . . so testing any vaccine on younger patients—say people in their 20s instead of their 40s—would be one safety precaution.  "For Pedro Vasconcelos, director of the National Reference Laboratory for Arboviruses in Brazil at the Evandro Chagas Institute, there is no time to lose. Even concerns about GBS, a condition treatable with pricey therapies including plasma exchange or injections of immunoglobulins, cannot push back vaccine trials. “We need to do better work still, but we need to move forward,” he says. “Every day with Zika is a new surprise.”

It is reported (Nature) that one type of vaccine could start trials by December (i.e. most probably will not). There are several vaccines that are thought to be about a year from being trialed. As these estimates are likely to be biased toward the most hopeful it is more likely that no trail will begin until after 1 July 2017

The US Government is still pushing to rush this through:
http://www.northlandsnewscenter.com/news/local/Future-legislation-will--375797721.html

The mad rush to tap the Zika grant spigot is very real, but it's difficult to know if any of this will result in a clinical vaccine trial this year. Two of the companies listed in "Nature" might start Phase 1 trials this year, but barely, and they may also be overstating the pace of their progress: http://www.nature.com/nbt/journal/v34/n3/fig_tab/nbt0316-221_T1.html Seems iffy, but where there are boatloads of grant money, there may be a way to come up with something fast, even if it is something meaningless. There is also the fact that a Zika vaccine has a relatively short window of opportunity to profit, as most people in affected areas develop immunity before reaching reproductive age. That has not yet happened in Brazil, because the virus is new there. But it will. Then the money will dry up. So I'll hang out around the consensus until there is more information.

This will get fast-tracked, but perhaps not until after the election or until someone in Ryan's district shows up with Zika.

http://www.pulseheadlines.com/zika-virus-structure-puts-scientists-vaccine-development/23876/ On Thursday, researchers have published for the first time the Zika virus’ structure, which may leave scientists near the development of a vaccine . . . . “The structure of the virus provides a map that shows potential regions of the virus that could be targeted by a therapeutic treatment, used to create an effective vaccine or to improve our ability to diagnose and distinguish Zika infection from that of other related viruses,” said Richard Kuhn, lead author and director of the Purdue Institute for Inflammation, Immunology and Infectious Diseases (PI4D).

Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, told reporters. "We believe we can get a vaccine," Fauci said, adding that he felt "cautiously optimistic" because scientists have produced vaccines against other flaviviruses, a group that includes Zika, yellow fever, dengue and West Nile. So far, Phase 1 clinical trials are slated to start by the end of summer or early fall of this year, he said. Phase 1 trials are small, and are held to evaluate whether a treatment is safe, what dosages are best and what side effects participants report. If the vaccines given in the Phase 1 trial pass muster and can induce an immune response against the virus, then scientists can proceed to Phase 2 by early 2017, Fauci said.

I've taken another look at my Daily Racing Form so I'm re-handicapping this race from scratch.  I now expect Innovio to finish second (sometime in the first half of 2017).  Innovio needed 4 months to get IND approval for its MERS vaccine.  They are now recruiting volunteers for their Phase 1 MERS trial.  This example sets the pace for Innovio Zika vaccine development.  Innovio has completed a rat study for its Zika vaccine.  It says it will now do a non-human primate study.  Perhaps this will take a few months.   At that point Innovio should be in a position to apply for an Zika vaccine IND.  If you add it up, everything would have to go perfectly for Innovio to begin a Phase 1 trial before January 1st.  Innovio might make it, but the odds are it won't cross the finish line until 2017.  Protein Sciences, another contender, appears to be trailing Innovio by some additional months.  I expect Protein Sciences to finish third. Where did i go wrong with my initial forecast?   Mainly, I just didn't pay enough attention to the biggest horse in the race -- the NIH.  I expected the NIH to follow a traditional role and be a promoter of Zika vaccine, but not a competitor in its development.  If this big horse steps into the starting gate, it becomes the automatic favorite.  It has huge competitive advantages compared to any private outfit.  It doesn't have to negotiate financing deals with investors or corporate partners.  It can shift money around and apply it quickly with confidence that future appropriations will fill any budget gaps.  Once a public health matter like Zika becomes a political issue, the NIH need have no concern about matters like market size or product profitability,  Additionally, the NIH has unique advantages in the regulatory arena.  It isn't going to be held up my any nitpicking reviews.  The NIH is the big horse.  It has pole position so it seems likely to win going away.

Until this year very little research has gone into Zika. National labs are working on it but not private labs. The prevailing attitude (correct or not) seems to be that Zika will burn itself out before a vaccine can be developed.

The question has nothing to do with whether people are helped, when an effective vaccine is developed and is not about rational global health policies.

Initial forecast. @RickRock's excellent analysis is noted.  I do believe that the Phase 1 timeline will be compressed by a variety of factors; accelerated vaccine development utilizing existing knowledge gleaned from the development of other flavivirus vaccine candidates; the use of either an emergency use or treatment IND or perhaps some other sort of accelerated application process given the effects of the virus, and lastly, the rapid spread of the virus expected here in the southeastern US as the weather warms. I would be remiss if I did not add that there will be tremendous political pressure to get a viable vaccine to market as well.

Having said that, RickRock provides a substantial analysis for a cautious estimate.@RickRock analysis: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/184435

Claims and press releases are flying around but the rate-limiting step for vaccine development seems to be the IND application.  There's a lot of hype about Zika, but without IND approval, you can't begin Phase I human testing.  Some of the initiatives are worth a look.  Innovia has announced that it will file an IND for a synthetic ZIKA vaccine that has been tested in rats.  The Innovia collaboration includes Gary Kobinger (Canadian official and expert) and GeneOne Life Sciences (South Korean contractor that owns a plasmid facility in Texas).  Drug developers like to create buzz.  It helps them raise money.  Of course, the disclaimer attached to Innovia's announcement advises that "clinical trials may not commence or be completed in time frames estimated." About six months ago, Innovia made a similar announcement about a MERS vaccine, but I can find no announcement about Innovia MERS IND approval.  Arguably MERS is a more serious disease than Zika.  Maybe the Innovia Zika IND approval process will move along faster.  If not, Innovia's announced plan to start Phase I trials in 2016 "may not commence in time frames estimated." Gary Kobinger was involved in Ebola vaccine development in in the past.  The development partner back then was a company called Defyrus.  The usual press releases appeared in 2011 and 2012.  The IND application wasn't filed until 2-3 years after that and it took a year to gain IND approval so Phase I human testing could begin. The Bahrat intiative in India claims to be ahead of the pack in Zika vaccine development.  What they seem to have is a vaccine candidate ready for pre-clinical trials (animal testing).  That needs to get done before they can even apply for an IND. Protein Sciences claims to be on a fast track for a Zika vaccine but they haven't actually made it yet.  There's no likelihood that it would be ready for human trials in 6-8 weeks.  The company says it might be ready for testing sometime soon.  That would be animal testing, not human testing.  After animal testing,, Protein Sciences would have to go through the IND application process.  Other research groups in Britain and Brazil have made announcements that they will also be launching initiatives to develop Zika vaccines.  It's likely that these are also start-up initiatives. Statements by Anthony Fauci, the pope of infectious diseases and vaccines, don't seem to be encouraging the thought that a Zika vaccine will be ready for human testing in the time frame of this question. Putting all this together, I'm tilting toward the back end of the answer array.  I could be wrong.  Maybe some political initiative will blossom and blow up the IND process.   Maybe someone, somewhere will give some human an experimental Zika vaccine.   It's also possible that the correct answer will be 100% -- not before July 1, 2017.  No pharmaceutical company that wants to sell a global product can avoid the IND process.   Incidentally, it isn't always easy to get any pharmaceutical company to make vaccines.  I think dengue languished in development for 20 years.  Last time I checked, I don't think there were any takers on chickungaya.  Most vaccine buyers are governments.   Most governments want to pay very low unit prices.  Many end customers are poor people in poor countries.  Vaccines usually aren't all that profitable.

Canadian scientist Gary Kobinger, part of a consortium working on the vaccine, told Reuters in an interview that the first stage of testing on humans could begin as early as August. 
. . . 
"The United States has two potential candidates for a Zika vaccine and may begin clinical trials in people by the end of this year, . . .
. .. .
"Kobinger, the lead scientist on this project from Quebec City's Laval University and head of special pathogens at Canada's National Microbiology Laboratory in Winnipeg, is working with the University of Pennsylvania, led by scientist David Weiner, Inovio Pharmaceuticals Inc (INO.O) and South Korea's GeneOne Life Science Inc (011000.KS). Joseph Kim, chief executive of Inovio, said the timeline to make the vaccine available by year's end is aggressive, but possible.
. . . 
Other vaccine candidates appear to be moving more slowly. The Sao Paulo-based Butantan Institute said last week it planned to develop a vaccine "in record time," although its director warned this was still likely to take three to five years.
